metadata.title: Physical Therapy for Animals
area of specialty: neurological rehabilitation (animal). animal rehabilitation is an identified special interest group in the orthopedic section of the american physical therapy association (apta)
description: Animal physical therapy involves using professional assessment and reasoning processes to make functional diagnoses and select appropriate physical interventions or treatments for animals. It is seen as complementary to, but different from, veterinary medicine in that the veterinary approach is to reach a pathoanatomic diagnosis and treat an animal medically or surgically
Physiotherapy treatments are selected to manage sensory and motor impairments for functional improvement and activity-specific performance
Animal rehabilitation originated as a way to help animals recover from surgery, as medical and surgical advances in veterinary medicine led to a demand for better care and more expertise

Physical therapy in veterinary practice still focuses on enhancing surgical recovery and maintaining a comfortable quality of life, but it has grown to include many other types of patients, including older animals with chronic conditions such as arthritis, obese animals with functional limitations, and healthy animals whose owners want them to perform at a higher athletic level
The practice of animal physical therapy requires specialized skills and training that include animal handling, anatomy, physiology, and pathology(1)
Many techniques, treatments, and rehabilitation regimens used on humans have been adapted for use in animals. Preliminary studies have shown promising results(2)

Animal physical therapists are usually licensed physical therapists who want to work with animals, but in some settings veterinarians, veterinary technicians, and physical therapy assistants may also evaluate and treat animals in order to restore and improve functional mobility, strength, and endurance
Recognized qualifications for the practice of physical therapy on animals are not legally defined in many countries(2)
In the United States, licensed physical therapists can obtain further education and training through continuing education programs

Massage therapists who are interested in further training and qualifications for animal acupressure and massage can visit the National Board of Certification for Animal Acupressure & Massage (NBCAAM) at www.nbcaam.org  or the International Association of Animal Massage & Bodywork at https://iaamb.org/

In the United Kingdom, members of the Association of Chartered Physiotherapists in Animal Therapy (ACPAT) are fully qualified chartered physiotherapists who have obtained further training and qualifications in physiotherapy for animals(1)
indications: The primary indications for animal physical therapy are: –Pain – due to chronic musculoskeletal disorders or a recent surgery or injury  –Tissue damage – wounds, fractures, soft-tissue  injuries –Functional limitations – impairments in the animal’s ability to move and function in daily life
reimbursement: Animal physical therapy is usually an out-of-pocket  expense. Some veterinary insurance companies will cover some of the costs Indications for animal physical therapy
contraindications precautions to test: Monitor for signs of discomfort or pain during examination. Unlike humans, animals cannot report their sensations. Obtain a description of the animal’s pain behaviors to watch for from the client or trainer

contraindications precautions to examina: Monitor for signs of discomfort or pain during examination. Unlike humans, animals cannot report their sensations. Obtain a description of the animal’s pain behaviors to watch for from the client or trainer

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document the history of the current complaint -Date of injury or surgery if applicable -Was onset sudden or insidious?

course of treatment.medical management: What treatment has animal received? Document any veterinary care that has been received, including surgical intervention, if applicable, immobilization, and any complications
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the veterinarian has prescribed; are they being taken?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Depend on the underlying condition being treated and may include the following:
Imaging studies such as x-rays,  computerized tomography (CT) scans, and/or magnetic resonance imaging (MRIs)
Laboratory tests (e.g., blood, serum, urine, feces)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture, herbal supplements) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether animal has had physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the signs/symptoms come on or areObtain a detailed description of pain behaviors from the client or trainer
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document whether symptoms are constant or intermittent and any other qualifying features provided by client or trainer
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Variability of heart rate or respiratory rate might suggest presence of pain or discomfort.(3) Patient-specific  signals that might indicate the animal’s pain level can include behaviors, activity level, appetite, tail carriage, facial expression, and vocalizations.(3) Objective assessment is difficult -Tools such as dolorimeters are being investigated to provide more objective measures of pain sensitivity, tolerance, and intensity(3)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (AM, mid-day, PM, night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Previous history of same/similar diagnosis Document any prior injuries, surgeries, or related conditions
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask client about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, orthopedic disorders, etc.
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Is the animal a sporting animal? Canine sporting activities include racing (e.g., greyhounds, sled dogs), field trial, hunting, herding, agility, search and rescue, and flyball/ disc.(4) Equine sporting activities include dressage, endurance riding, show jumping, vaulting, polo, racing, driving, and rodeo. Describe the skills and behaviors required for the animal’s particular sport or work
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Is the animal’s ability to perform functional activities such as eating, drinking, grooming, and eliminating limited? Are any assistive devices in use? Devices can increase an animal’s independence and prevent complications. Examples include booties, slings, two-wheeled and four-wheeled  carts, and prosthetics(5)
social and occupational history.living environment: Describe the animal’s living environment and any related limitations. Who is the animal’s primary caretaker?

relevant tests and measures.general: ›Relevant tests and measures  (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting) •Anthropomorphic characteristics: Measure height, length, weight, and girth (e.g., of chest or extremities) as indicated. Calculation of weight: height ratio can be used to determine body composition(3) –Rules for the systematic measurement of various animals should be observed -Specialized measuring sticks, compasses, and tapes may be employed -Animal should be standing on level ground –Morphometric measurement of peripheral edema or joint effusion may be made circumferentially or volumetrically
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Document any use of assistive or adaptive devices and their appropriateness and fit –Boots or booties – can be used to protect an animal’s feet from trauma (e.g., cold, glass, or debris in working dogs) or repetitive sport injury, or when a neurological deficit affects proprioception –Slings – aid in transitioning a recumbent animal to a standing position and may be used to assist ambulation –Carts – can be used to provide full body support (e.g., “canine wheelchairs”) –Orthotics –can  be used for joint protection, rest, immobilization, movement assistance, and correction -If orthotics are in use, examine them for wear and cleanliness -Examine the underlying soft tissues for breakdown or damage -Reassessment and modification of orthotics should be performed regularly as animal’s status changes –Prosthetics – not commonly used in quadrupeds that adapt well to 3-legged  gait. One indication would be a bilateral amputation that leaves an animal unable to walk(5) -When present, examine the residual limb and all components of the prosthetic (the suspension system, the socket, the shank, and the ground contact [artificial foot])(5)
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess balance statically and dynamically –Assess animal’s ability to maintain upright position while perturbation is applied
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Fatigue may be evident if the animal lies down or leaves the area during activity(6)
relevant tests and measures.circulation: In many animals, gum color is an indicator of circulation. Gums should be pink and moist in horses, dogs, and catsAssess as indicatedFunctional mobility includes all of the postures and movements used in daily function, including maintenance of static lying, sitting, and standing postures and dynamic transitions to and from these positions
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Perform a qualitative and quantitative evaluation of static and dynamic gait characteristics in standing, walking, and trotting (galloping, running) as indicated –Kinematic gait analysis may be performed using electrogoniometry or computer-assisted  videography where available –Force plate or pressure sensor assessment of ground reaction forces and contact time may be performed if specialized equipment is available –Most commonly, qualitative gait analysis is performed. Observe and describe deviations of gait patterns using a scheme designed for the animal in question -Note cadence, stance and swing time, weight-bearing quality and frequency, and active ROM (AROM) -EMG can be used to assess muscle activation patterns –A variety of “lameness scores” used by veterinary professionals to assess antalgic gait patterns exist(3)Assess the quantity and quality (e.g., crepitation) of and presence of pain during passive ROM (PROM) –Manual testing techniques should be used to detect laxity in the hip joint in dogs. Standard tests are the Barlow, Barden, and Ortolani tests(7) –Early signs of joint disease in horses are subtle and are often confused with behavioral problems(8)Describe movement patterns, making note of any abnormalities in muscle tone or coordination. Observe for signs of learned nonuse  –Subtle changes in muscle tone and mass, symmetry, and reflex movements, especially in the equine back and quarters, may be indicative of (impending) fracture(9) -Based on a retrospective study of records of 513 thoroughbred racehorses(9) -Presence of pelvic bony asymmetry, muscle atrophy of the quarters, reduced reflexive dorsi- and/or ventroflexion, and spasm or tenderness on palpation of gluteal muscles were associated with subsequent fracture diagnosis -Early detection of impending pelvic or hind-limb  fracture may be possible during routine physiotherapy assessment and might reduce the incidence of catastrophic fractures
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Traditional methods of muscle strength measurement (e.g., manual muscle testing) are not readily applicable to the animal population(3) –Muscle strength can be estimated by measuring muscle mass with diagnostic ultrasound, CT scan, or MRI(3) -Repeat measurements are not economical or feasible in animal rehabilitation -Girth measurements of the muscle belly correlate well with muscle mass in dogs(3) -Diminished muscle mass is a key finding in dogs with dysplastic hips as early as 8 weeks of age(7) –Subjective descriptions of functional strength may also be used
observation inspection palpation includi: Inspect any wounds, documenting size, color, thickness, edges, and any signs of infection such as swelling, redness, and purulent drainage(10)
Inspect for pressure sores in immobilized animals(10) -Decubital ulcers have been reported as common complications of prolonged recumbency in horses(11)
Palpate the musculoskeletal structures to assess tissue temperature, mobility, and tension(8)
Examine horses’ hooves -The hoof provides the first line of defense against ground-impact  shock(8) -Inadequate hoof integrity can contribute to repetitive microtrauma elsewhere
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess for symmetry and alignment –Quantitative assessment of static weight-bearing  and distribution in small animals may be assessed by placing one paw on each of four bathroom weigh scales, or with one paw on a sphygmomanometer cuff inflated to a specific pressure(3) –Quadruped biofeedback systems using pressure -sensing pads may be used where available(3)
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Measure AROM and PROM as indicated using goniometer –When measuring PROM, the clinician should take care to eliminate the effects of passive insufficiency (the inability of a 2-joint  muscle to stretch to allow full ROM of both joints simultaneously)(3)
relevant tests and measures.self-care activities of daily living: Assess animal’s ability to perform activities such as eating, drinking, grooming, and eliminating(3) –There are many functional scores and scales available; however, most lack evidence of reliability, validity, or correlation(3) -Canine FIM -Canine Timed Up and Go (TUG) test -Bioarth Functional Evaluation Scale
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Sensory examination is best done in a quiet room free of distractions. Cutaneous testing may be done with a small pinch applied only to the skin, taking care to avoid deeper structures. A small instrument such as a hemostat can be used. The pinch should be gentle at first and gradually increased until the animal responds. The response may be a reflex (e.g., withdrawal) or an indication of conscious awareness of the stimulus (e.g., growl, cry, bite). Stimulating an area of normal innervation first may allow the clinician to observe the animal’s normal response, before testing the area of suspected abnormality(12)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Manual tests based on the amount of hypo-  or hypermobility and quality of movement at a joint and pain provocation tests similar to those used in humans are supported by research for use in horses(13) and dogs(7) -Pelvis alignment – simultaneous palpation of ischial tuberosities and iliac crests  -Piriformis pain tolerance and sacrotuberous ligament palpation – manually strumming over each of the piriformis muscles -Pain provocation stress tests – a thigh thrust technique modified from human use is hypothesized to stress the dorsal sacroiliac ligaments -Kinematic testing – passive flexion and extension of the hip while the examiner palpates the quality and quantity of movement of the iliac spines -Trendelenburg testing – in dogs, this human test is modified by slowly lifting one hind leg off the ground and watching for a hip drop or body shift -Flexibility testing – evaluation of the passive elongation of the hamstrings, piriformis, sartorius, iliopsoas, adductors, latissimus dorsi, tensor fascia latae, and obliques abdominals should be compared side to side -Shear tests –translatory  movement assessment requiring ability to detect end feels

contraindications precautions: Manual therapy is generally contraindicated in the presence of fractures, acute inflammatory or infectious joint disease, osteomyelitis, ankylosis, bleeding disorders, progressive neurologic signs, and primary or metastatic tumors(14)
Severe articular instability (e.g., joint subluxation) is a contraindication for manipulation(14)

In horses, static compression caused by vertebral malformation and dynamic lesions caused by vertebral segment hypermobility are contraindications for cervical manipulation; however, adjacent hypomobile regions may be treated with mobilization or manipulation(14)
Hydrotherapy is contraindicated in the presence of fever, acute joint infections, metabolic diseases, open wounds, or severe skin changes
No animal should be left unattended during hydrotherapy due to aspiration and drowning risk(2)
Harnesses or flotation devices(6) should be used
Hydrotherapy may be an uncommon modality to use with cats, in comparison to dogs and horses, but is not contraindicated and may be achievable and beneficial in some cases(2)
The therapist should accompany the nervous cat into the water to provide assistance and reassurance
Duration of hydrotherapy sessions should initially be short (e.g., 5 minutes) and gradually increased as tolerance improves(6)
Horses are naturally claustrophobic and may require time to adjust to this type of exercise. Mild sedation may be required for the initial underwater sessions(8)
Horses may overheat if the exercise is too strenuous or the water too warm
The water supply for underwater treadmills must be filtered, chemically treated, and kept around 62°C(8)
The primary precaution for use of cryotherapy is the avoidance of frostbite
Inspecting the skin every few minutes and avoiding prolonged application is recommended
It is difficult to check skin color on animals because of pigmentation and hair. Use of a timer is recommended, and ice should never be applied directly on the animal
Presence of cardiac or respiratory disease
Uncovered open wounds
Ischemic areas
Risk of overheating while immersed in heated whirlpool
Use caution in areas of decreased sensation
Skin response is difficult to monitor because of pigmentation and hair
Open or infected wounds
Electric heating pads and infrared lamps pose a higher risk of burns than warm water, and should not be used on sedated, anesthetized, or insensate animals
Active bleeding
Acute inflammation
Cardiac insufficiency
Impaired circulation in the area to be treated
Fever
Malignancy
Poor body heat regulation
Avoid direct exposure to cardiac pacemakers, carotid sinus, cervical ganglia, eyes, ears, heart, lumbar and abdominal areas in pregnant animals, testes, and contaminated wounds
Avoid the physes in immature animals
Areas with bony prominences, decreased blood circulation, acute injuries, and areas of decreased sensation
Plastic and metal implants
Unlike human patients, animals cannot tell the therapist if they begin to feel discomfort or overheating
Maintain ultrasound equipment according to the standards and regulations of the relevant regulatory agency, such as the Food and Drug Administration (FDA)in the United States

Avoid exposure to cardiac pacemakers, the carotid sinus, cervical ganglia, eyes, ears, the heart, lumbar and abdominal areas in pregnant animals, areas near malignant growths, areas of decreased sensation, areas of thrombosis or thrombophlebitis, and animals with seizure disorders and any time active movement is contraindicated(15,27)
Verify output accuracy and timer accuracy of equipment
Tissue damage by thermal or mechanical mechanisms can occur if energy levels or number of shocks used are too high
Shock waves should not be delivered over lung, brain, major blood vessels, nerves, tumors, or a gravid uterus
ESWT is contraindicated in infectious arthritis, immune-mediated  joint disease, neoplastic disease, acute unstable fractures, and neurologic deficits
To ensure adequate dosage, the animal’s hair should be clipped, because 50-90%  of the light may be absorbed by the hair
Avoid treatment over fontanelles or growth plates of immature animals, treatment over malignancies, treatment over photosensitive areas of the skin, and treatment directly into the cornea
Pregnancy is a precaution

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Physical therapy is appropriate for many conditions, including arthritis, postoperative conditions, healed fractures, neurological impairments, tendinitis, sprains, and strains, and for general conditioning in order to maximize function and improve activity-specific  performance of animals treatment _ _ MassageIntroduce new stimuli as animal’s comfort level increasesInvolve family members in treatment Decreased functional abilityImprove functional abilityTherapeutic exercise _ Functional activities such as walking up and down hills, agility training, jumping from graduated heights, pulling, retrieving, running, and swimmingGradual return to sporting or work activity as indicatedInstruct owner or trainer in home program of exercise .
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: The rehabilitation team may include a veterinarian, veterinary surgeon, physical therapist, veterinary technician, and physical therapy aide Sporting and work animals may have a rider or driver and/or a trainer or handler Referral to a nutritionist is indicated for obese animals Referral to an animal behavior specialist as indicated
treatment summary: Therapeutic exercise –An organized exercise regimen can be beneficial for weight management in obese animals -In a small study conducted in the United States, eight obese dogs were put on a 3-month  weight loss program that included dietary restrictions and exercise. Results showed significant decreases in thoracic and abdominal girth and a mean weight loss of 18.9% of starting weight(17)  -Exercise included lead walks and underwater treadmill exercise -Session duration and treadmill speed were tailored to the capabilities of the animal -Median distance walked was 0.6 miles per session to start and increased sequentially over the study -Owners attended weekly education lectures on pet health during the course of the study -The weight loss obtained was greater than had been previously reported from caloric restriction or drug therapy, which suggests that including exercise and client education may improve the rate of weight loss -Activity through play has been found most effective for increasing activity in obese cats(2) –Strengthening and endurance exercises should follow the overload principle(18) –Principles of specificity should be applied to a conditioning program(18) -Exercises should be selected based on the animal’s function and activity (e.g., sled dogs should be trained pulling sleds, not swimming) –Adequate rest is required to reduce the risk of overuse injuries(18) –As it has in humans, immobilization has been shown to lead to loss of joint motion in animals(18) -Early protected activity, including exercises promoting joint ROM, may be beneficial(18)

Hydrotherapy –Hydrotherapy includes swimming and the use of underwater treadmills for active assisted exercise(8,19) -Water depth may be varied when using aqua-treadmills to make use of buoyancy to encourage walking without full weight-bearing(8,19) -The quantity of water in the treadmill unit is raised or lowered to accommodate horses or dogs of different sizes and to vary the amount of weight-bearing -Controlled clinical studies are needed. There is minimal research evidence on the effectiveness of hydrotherapy for leg injuries(19) -Increased healing speed has been reported in a case series

Modalities –Physical agent modalities can be used as an adjunctive treatment to reduce swelling, relieve pain, enhance healing, increase muscle strength, and alter the mechanical properties of soft tissues in the rehabilitation of animals(27) –Application of cold can be used for acute soft tissue injuries to reduce inflammation and pain -Cold can be applied in many forms, such as tubs of slush, frozen bandages, and ice massage(8,27) -Studies of the application of cold to reduce body or local tissue temperature have found that prolonged or repeated ice water cooling is the most effective for cooling equine limbs(19) -Studies of the effectiveness of cryotherapy in horses are limited(19) –Cold compresses are effective in reducing soft tissue swelling after ligament repair in dogs(20) -A randomized controlled trial compared use of cold compresses, bandaging, and microcurrent electrical stimulation to reduce postoperative tissue swelling -Use of cold compresses alone or with a bandage, or using microcurrent stimulation with a bandage, were more effective than a bandage alone –More research is needed in dogs to determine the amount and duration of tissue cooling with various forms of cold applications(27) -The recommended method of cold application depends on the therapeutic goal, the stage of healing, and the location and size of the area to be treated –Various heating modalities may be used to increase blood flow, tissue metabolism, and tissue extensibility(19) -Generally gel packs and water baths elevate tissue temperature close to the surface only, with minimal effects more than 1.5-2  cm under the skin(19) -Therapeutic ultrasound is primarily used to produce deeper heating (1.0-3.0  cm depth of penetration with 3.3 MHz US, and 2.0-5.0  cm depth of penetration with 1.0 MHz US)(27) –Therapeutic ultrasound -Therapeutic ultrasound can be used to produce thermal effects such as increased blood flow, decreased pain, and increased flexibility in deep tissue(8,19)  -Studies on the effect of ultrasound on equine tendon healing indicate that treated tendons had better clinical results, less degeneration, and less inflammation than controls(19) -Case studies also report positive results of ultrasound in a variety of musculoskeletal conditions in horses, but no control groups were available(19) -A coupling medium, such as a commercially available coupling gel pad cushion, must be placed between the sound head and the tissue surface(27) –LLLT -There is no evidence for clinical effectiveness of LLLT in horses(19) -In vitro studies have found some thermal effects on cartilage healing(19) -Controlled clinical testing in horses is required –Electrical stimulation can be used for pain control and for muscle strengthening(27) -There are few high-quality  studies of the use of transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) for pain relief in veterinary medicine(27) -A combination of dietary management and intensive physiotherapy that included TENS was effective for reducing disability in a study that involved obese dogs with osteoarthritis -Pain relief from TENS application in dogs is reported to be greatest immediately after treatment -Further study of use of TENS in dogs is needed to establish its effectiveness and appropriate parameters -Electrical stimulation for muscle strengthening (neuromuscular electrical stimulation [NMES]) has numerous applications in small animals, including to prevent atrophy postoperatively(27) -A muzzle may need to be applied to the animal during the initial treatment. In some cases, tranquilization may be necessary -Most dogs tolerate NMES well, but some may find the sensation unpleasant and vocalize or try to run -The current should be turned up very slowly to allow the dog to get used to the sensation gradually –Electro acupuncture has been reported to be effective for pain relief in animals(21,22,23) -Electro acupuncture can reduce postoperative analgesic requirements in dogs(21) -Based on a randomized controlled trial in Brazil involving 30 dogs undergoing mastectomy -Dogs were randomly assigned to receive morphine, electro acupuncture, or sham treatment -Supplemental morphine was administered if postoperative pain was not sufficiently controlled based on a numerical rating scale that incorporated heart rate, respiration rate, arterial blood pressure, salivation, vocalization, agitation, and response to palpation -A combination of conventional medicine and either electro acupuncture or acupuncture may be beneficial for treatment of intervertebral disc herniation in dogs(22) -Based on a study conducted in South Korea that included 80 paraplegic dogs -The combination of electro acupuncture or acupuncture with conventional medicine was more effective than conventional medicine alone in recovering ambulation, relieving back pain, and decreasing relapse in a retrospective study -Conventional medicine consisted of prednisone therapy –ESWT has been used in horses for treating ligament desmitis, tendinopathies, navicular disease, back pain, osteoarthritis, and stress fractures, and in dogs to treat tendinitis, desmitis, spondylosis, nonunion fractures, and osteoarthritis(16) -The animal typically is sedated for treatment with ESWT

Manual therapy –Most of the current knowledge about equine manual therapy is extrapolated from human techniques and applied to horses –Manual therapy may help in the management of select musculoskeletal injuries in performance horses and in musculoskeletal conditions that are chronic, recurring, or not responding to conventional veterinary care –Manual therapy techniques are considered to produce physiological effects in local tissues, on sensory and motor components of the neuromusculoskeletal system, and at a psychological or behavioral level(14) -Techniques used with horses include therapeutic touch for pain; massage for muscle hypertonicity, soft tissue restriction, and pain; stretching for soft-tissue  restriction and joint stiffness; soft-tissue  mobilization for soft-tissue  restriction and pain; joint mobilization for joint stiffness and pain; and joint manipulation for joint stiffness, pain, and muscle hypertonicity(14)  -In horses, massage therapy has been shown to reduce stress-related  behavior(14) -Joint mobilization typically is applied with oscillatory forces within physiological ROM and graded by the amount of available joint motion used(14) -Tui na , an ancient Chinese form of acupressure, uses techniques of “dredging” or clearing the meridians through grasping, holding, kneading, pressing, pounding, pushing, rolling, and rubbing, to which animals are highly responsive(26) -There are 11 different hand techniques (e.g., Tui Fa, Rou Fa ), similar to massage, each with a subset of at least three different movement patterns, which affect the meridians and specific acupoints -Movement techniques are soothing and repetitive -Manipulation is characterized by application of high-velocity,  low-amplitude  thrusts that move a joint or segment beyond its physiological ROM -Anecdotal and clinical evidence suggests that manipulation is an effective adjunctive treatment for musculoskeletal disorders in horses(14) -Manipulation is thought to be more effective than mobilization for restoring normal joint motion and thus decreasing the risk of reinjury(14) –Both spinal mobilization and spinal manipulation therapy applied to horses have been found to improve spinal flexibility -In a United States study that included 24 actively ridden horses, dorsoventral displacement of the trunk increased after mobilization and manipulation(24) -Spinal mobilization had a delayed effect on increasing flexibility, whereas manipulation had an immediate effect and produced larger increases in displacement

Neurological rehabilitation –Physiotherapy techniques adapted from those used in humans have been reported to be effective in treating animals with neurological disorders -A case report from Finland reported the successful use of physiotherapy to aid recovery of a 2-week-old foal with generalized tetanus(11) -The foal presented in a recumbent position and demonstrated extension and tetany of all four limbs, the head, and the neck when lifted to a standing position. V oluntary movement was not possible due to the tetany and hyperresponsiveness to tactile and auditory stimuli -Physiotherapy goals included reducing sensitivity to stimuli; treating pain resulting from spasticity and spasms; reducing spasticity and inhibiting extensor tone; preventing abnormal positions in limbs and torso; preventing respiratory complications, skin lesions, and secondary trauma from recumbency; achieving normal ROM; and enabling voluntary movement -Treatment included desensitization through touch and movement, positioning, massage and PROM exercises, weight-bearing  with use of standing frame, proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation (PNF), stretching, active exercise, respiratory physiotherapy, and manual facilitation techniques -Treatment lasted 6 weeks and was divided into 3 phases: passive phase, assistive phase, and active phase -At 6- and 12-month  follow-up  examinations, the foal had no detectable deficits . outcome measures: There is a void in published literature regarding outcome measures for animal rehabilitation practice

Modified versions of valid standardized questionnaires commonly used in physical therapy can be applied but should firstbe validated to kinetic, kinematic, diagnostic imaging, and other objective measures(3)

maintenance or prevention: A home program may be beneficial for maintenance of gains obtained
Pet owners can be trained to apply massage, PROM, and exercises Specialized exercise equipment (e.g., exercise balls) and assistive devices can be purchased for home use

Obese animals are at increased risk for injuries, orthopedic disease,(25) diabetes,(25) and pressure sores(10) Attaining and maintaining ideal body weight is recommended as a preventive measure Client Education
